I'm happy to chat, but it sounds like you set the wheels in motion, and we can only try to pick up the pieces of what is left later.

"Conversation with Kari after the meeting with Adrian was heartbreaking. What he communicated to her in an honest and open environment was
incredibly brave and I need to respect and frankly have no choice but to take action on his own expressed words. She made it clear to me if she believes
he is in, or put in an unsafe situation, she must take action. That is her obligation."
This email discusses the AD meeting, as per last night. You said you heard Adrian say these things yourself, but you don't say that here. You say that
Kari discussed it with you afterward. Which was it? I agree that Kari would take action if safety were a concern. She has not done that.
"How to structure plans moving forward is now being directly addressed to ensure complete safety. "
Who is addressing this? Is this you solo with the web? Kari explicitly said she will not participate in this, so I'd love to know who is 'structuring your
plan' and what their qualifications are, given the PHD was not qualified. I am sure you would want to share that with their father, right?
I'm sure you can understand why I am trying to understand the truth after finding out last week that you were actually sitting in the same room with
Adrian when he reportedly said things in conflict with Dr Brown's contemporaneous notes conveying Adrian's true feelings.

The worst case we agreed to with Max and Adrian was that they both exercised free will to visit, so what do you tell AD about seeing me and his own
choice? Does he even have that anymore?

I know you are busy, but these are timely and important so even an "ack" is better than ignoring it.
-robert

Do you have a preference for day or time?
So, per the free will part, I get you heard him say that one thing in one session with you there. We also know, and it has been noted that both Max and
Adrian say, " Parent, please," if you are there.
So, my point has always been that they have been progressively turned against me over time.
So, while documenting all of our exchanges, there is a definite change from all last year's texts and even the most recent events. He clearly was at a
place where he called on me, often, to do stuff with him and talk about tough things. All of that has changed since April started.
I think it would be in our best interests to try and figure out why he decided to turn against Dad and start parroting your POV. I know that is not our
intent, but perhaps this is an example of the "law of unintended consequence" you did not see coming. Should we share notes to discuss?
I think we are on the same team, agree?

I’m trying to have a conversation about what is transpired with them since July. It feels relevant because it’s a clear trajectory. .
Actually, you can just read them for yourself. I don’t need to put any spin on it. Please don’t make an offer to help inform the discussion of threat.
Please let me know if there’s anything I can do today. I’ll consider this offer closed. And will not ask again to paint a fuller picture. Of what has
transpired.
Have a great day

Sent:04/24/2024 at 09:34 AM
From:Christine Moyer
To:Robert Moyer (First Viewed: 04/24/2024 at 10:51 AM)
Subject:Re: Adrian

Message 2572 of 4024
Everything you send on this topic now says "we" and "us." But it is not us as Max and Adrain's parents. It is you and Annalisa. Every comment is
about what you and Annalisa are doing after my one request, which was that "we" and "us" would be the actual parents of Max and Adrian.
You say I am threatening you by asking to share notes on what has transpired on your watch. They will be shared anyway, but I hoped that you and I,
as "we" and "us," could partner together on the children we brought into this world, not you and an attorney vs. me and an attorney.
Current Proposal:
- Christine and Annalisa
Rejected Proposals:
- Christine and Robert, the Moyer parents
- Yurushka and the Moyers (rejected: regular dinners)
- Debbie and the Moyers (rejected: new traditions)
- Dr Brown and the Moyers (rejected: two parenting plans)
The entire descent into chaos and thoughts of self-harm started with the team you choose when we were in Debbie's office. We agreed that if you
would not let me be involved with the family for the holidays, I would get a place in Bellevue to begin "new traditions."
This was horrible and painful to me, but I did it at a significant cost to our fiscal health because it was what we agreed was best for the kids. Then you
pulled out and attributed it to the plan Annalisa had advised. You said it plain as day to Debbie, and I have plenty of details.
Since it has been Kabuki theatre with you, over and over, we see professionals and get advice, spending Dec-Feb to get Dr Brown's feedback. And with
the brief exception of the end of December, you defer to the plan you and Annalisa have devised instead of recommendations.
I want to ensure you do not consider this a threat. When I see a months-long pattern of rejecting professional advice, refusing to work with me
constructively, and then asking to repeat the way we got here as your only next step, I am not so inclined based on the past.
For that matter, who on earth would be? Do you have a single positive thing to show for your plans? I was doing great with both our kids till July 4th,
and then July 5th. Our history shows that included you too. But under your watch, Max won't see me, and AD is considering suicide.
If I were the father in an awful book you were reading... would you really say, "Hell, yes! For Max and Adrian's sake, you gotta go with what got you
there. It has been amazing and healing advice so far. The Moyer's are doing better than ever with Christine at the helm now?"
Your watch, your plan, your results = another Christine and Annalisa plan?
I don't get this...

Message 2574 of 4024
As you saw in my communication to SAAS attendance, Max hurt his foot and is resting today per recommendation from the Dr to elevate and ice for
24 hours.
Tuesday, he jumped over a chair at school and landed on it funny. I picked Max and Adrain up from the bus stop after school per regular schedule,
and he informed me what happened, it hurt but was fine. I observed it was slightly swollen, and we elevated and iced and gave him a Motrin. We
discussed an urgent care visit, but decided against it, as it seemed to be ok and he was walking fine but a little tender.
Max went to school the next day (yesterday) as normal. I dropped Adrain and Max directly at school as Adrian was leaving for camp. Max said it was
tender, but declined using a crutch or boot, as he deemed unnecessarily based on pain level at that time. During the day, he called and indicated it was
hurting a little more, and we agreed to have it checked out, out of abundance of caution. I made an 8pm appointment at Seattle Childrens Urgent
Care, as he wanted to attend the after school Tech Theater program. I picked up from his bus stop at 7pm, and we visited Seattle Childrens at 8pm.
Upon examination, they suggested an xray to rule out broken bones, and confirmed it was in fact just bruised. Said to take the day off school today to
rest and elevate, continuing the care we had been doing.
He is in good spirits.
Let me know if any questions.
Sent:04/25/2024 at 08:20 AM
From:Christine Moyer
To:Robert Moyer (First Viewed: 04/25/2024 at 08:58 AM)
Subject:Max Foot
Message 2575 of 4024
I see in my email Max had an accident that required emergency medical attention. I want to confirm he is Ok, and does not need anything additional?
Please confirm.
I don't see anything here. I am blocked by you on any other way to communicate because of the incorrect RO that you and Annalisa refuse to update
months after saying it was filed by mistake. Despite Max and I being in the best place we had for years, it appears I am blocked now on Max's phone.
And I get worried because I think we agree that for various personal experiences, I have a pretty deep background on urgent/orthopedic/general care
situations. If you disagree, I'm not arguing.
I remind you emergencies are not planned or scheduled, so we need a way to communicate, but I can't seem to get that to resonate with you.
If AD requires urgent care when he is over next, and I have to rush him to see someone, I assume this is the rule we play by? No call, you will find out
when you find out. Maybe I'll respond.
I was not healthy before. I admit that. I needed help. I had the strength and courage to address that with four years of DBT and EMDR. I got better.
But you act like I am that same guy.

Christine-
I began writing the email before yours landed. I did not choose to ignore it. It was not there. As I started it I paused to make coffee. I assume you have
paused during a draft before?
“Max hurt his foot. Out of abundance Of caution I took him to Seattle children’s urgent care last night. X-rays did not show anything broken but
clearly bruised. Asked he elevate, ice and rest for 24 hours, so stay home and come back in 5 days if no improvement. “
I did not mischaracterize anything. In your original email it lacked any of the details you have since provided. I was going on the very limited info I
have living out of the loop.
I am not going to tell you how to behave, but you seem toxic. You say things and make accusations that are unnecessary and inflammatory. Do you
expect that to help our kids situation?
Please remember who, as parents, we need to focus on. I know who I was once upon a time. I realize you will never forgive me and will always want to
destroy me. But let’s put Max and AD first, please.
- robert

Message 2593 of 4024
... But it's not for lack of trying. I told you in Kari’s office weeks ago that I had done a lot of soul-searching and had done a lot of reflection on our
conversations and the way things happened. I told you then that I wanted to work with you on a parenting plan that took my past behavior into
account. I told you I am not fighting you. I am not trying to point the finger or put the blame on you. I am accountable for my own actions and
acknowledge them.
And that's why it's so hard to talk to you now as you still can't find a way to hear me. You are my family. I'm trying to own what I did. I'm trying to
get better for god's sake. And that's why I would like to know what the boys are saying. I'm not in a scoreboarding exercise against you. We are their
parents and we're trying to do right by them. All I have is the information that I have from them and therapists. And must make my judgment based
on that.
But now you're saying that you've done some investigation, and I should go talk to Hamlin Robin and SAAS, and that you have secret diaries. You
suggested I go do my own research and talk to these people, too. I can do that, but I would rather work with you to arrive at a common viewpoint or
at least share the same info to make informed decisions in our boy’s best interest. I'm trying to work with you for the sake of the kids.
But you just don't let me agree with you, and you want to keep it all the secret. I have no idea how to get through to you. You seem so dead set on my
destruction that you will not acknowledge or help me be a better father, you just want to win. I don't get that, Christine. it's not winning if they lose. I
want to know all I can about Max and Adrian so I can be a better father to them. I hope we all deserve that. Please consider my thoughts.
-robert
Sent:04/26/2024 at 08:32 PM
From:Robert Moyer
To:Christine Moyer (First Viewed: 04/26/2024 at 09:26 PM)
Subject:I can't agree with you...

<<How long?>>

willing to consider alternatives suggested by Robert.
<<You did not. I have tried hard and you have refused to entertain any discussions whatsoever >>
I will not say that negotiating additional time is conditioned on a response to Ms. Moyer’s proposal,
<< I am taking you up on this promise. I have spent 10 minutes with Adrian in the last two weeks. I asked how long I can spend with him and all you
keep doing in pushing the PP that is supposedly 'not conditional' on the additional time you offered.>>
<< I am asking if you will follow through on the characterization expressed by your attorney, who you insist everything goes through. I have expressed
my concerns and desire to work with you but you won't. So since you refuse to do that, I'll go back to the source as you requested, Annalisa, and see if
that will break the ice. Can we discuss the PP as she said you would? Can I have the 8 unconditional hours as she noted? It's all there, is it real or not?
Thanks!>>

Message 2596 of 4024
This could not be more a parenting issue.
Per below, Annelisa says the eight hours and the parenting plan are not contingent on each other. You said I need to go through Annisa. I am taking
her at her word and asking you so I can go back through Lisa to Ann Lisa to say that I have taken you on your word, for her to tell you .

I hope you will take ten seconds and consider this from something I am reading on navigating co-parenting challenges in an acrimonious divorce. I
hope at some point we share the view that all of our kids should have a healthy relationship with us both.
It’s not a win for you to have them hate me like you do. We did have some amazing time as a family that is being completely scrubbed from their mind
to focus solely on the negative. And at the same time, I have no way to have healthy conversations to heal.

When a parent will not show forgiveness to the other and openly harbors resentment, it will have significant implications for a child's development
and worldview. Not eliminating one parent from a child's life, despite challenging dynamics, is crucial for several reasons, to all involved, particularly
in teaching healthier emotional and interpersonal skills for all:

resolving conflicts is acceptable behavior. This will impact how the child handles conflicts in their own relationships throughout life. Demonstrating
forgiveness and conflict resolution, even in difficult situations, teaches children about empathy, understanding, and the complexities of human
relationships.

Removing a parent from a child's life will lead to emotional distress and issues such as anxiety and depression. When this separation is compounded
by visible resentment by one parent, the child will be taught to associate relationships with perpetual conflict and negativity, which can hinder their
emotional development. It’s critical to remember how you want your child to be as their own adult.

A child's identity is shaped by their understanding of and relationships with their parents. Witnessing ongoing resentment will instill feelings of
insecurity and doubt, potentially leading to issues with self-esteem and self-worth as the child might feel they are somehow at fault or inherently
problematic. While unreasonable, a child will likely blame themselves for not stopping regrettable behavior.

Learning from the behavior of parents is a primary way children develop social skills. If they see that one parent never forgives the other, they will
emulate this inability to forgive in their own social interactions, affecting friendships and other relationships. Conversely, if they see forgiveness and
Sent:04/28/2024 at 08:20 AM
From:Robert Moyer
To:Christine Moyer (First Viewed: 04/28/2024 at 12:37 PM)
Subject:For Your Consideration

compassion, they will value these traits.

Children model their future relationships on their interpretations of their parents' interactions. Exposure to unresolved resentment will predispose a
child to struggle with trust and to potentially replicate such dynamics in their own adult relationships. It is critically important to see how parents deal
with past situations even if there might have been conflict. This is true to life and they are learning important values now.

Maintaining contact with both parents, when safe and possible, allows the child to receive a more balanced perspective on interpersonal relationships.
It helps them see multiple sides to situations and to understand that even people can have flaws yet still be worthy of love and connection. They learn
not to shut people out and to be compassionate.

child's right to have a relationship with both parents. Cutting off a parent without substantial reasons can contravene these principles and potentially
harm the child in the long run. When a child is cut off from another parent legal remedies should be perused. Unless there is active abuse, this is not
healthy.
It is essential, therefore, to foster an environment where forgiveness and reconciliation are valued, not only for the immediate benefit of the child's
emotional environment but also for their long-term ability to build and sustain healthy relationships.
Professional support from counselors or therapists can be vital in navigating these complex family dynamics, focusing on the child’s best interests,
helping all to move towards a more positive and constructive relationship without ostracizing a parent.
Again, I am asking to have a mental health discussion for our kids, free of judgment or finger pointing. How we got to this place is less material than
recognizing we are here and providing a way for us all to heal in a safe and therapeutic way. Separation is not the way.
I am not having that discussion with the architect of the “holiday freeze” plan that kicked this off in Nov.
Please advise...
-robert
